raw_text:
Calder fears for Scottish rugby
 
 Former Scotland international Finlay Calder fears civil war at the SRU could seriously hamper his country's RBS Six Nations campaign.
 
 Four members of the executive board, including the chairman, David Mackay, have resigned after a simmering row. And Calder said: "This is terrible news for every level of Scottish rugby. "David is a successful businessman and I thought that if anybody could transform the negative atmosphere and rising debt level, it was him." Mackay's executive board has been in a power struggle with the general committee, which contains members elected by Scotland's club sides. "He has been driven out by people who seem happier waging civil war than addressing the central issue that professional rugby can't be run by amateurs," said Calder.
 
 "In fact, I don't understand why we are still having this argument 10 years after professionalism arrived. "But I don't believe the rest of the SRU will take this lying down. "I think the banks will be dismayed at this decision and, ultimately, it is them who pull the strings. "So I wouldn't be surprised if they reviewed their position. But, in the wider picture, what message does this send out?" He thought the work of Scotland's coaches, who have been attempting to arrest the decline of the national side, would be made much more difficult. "Matt Williams and Willie Anderson must be wondering, 'what have we walked into here?'" said Calder. "And we can now expect weeks of arguments and acrimony just at a time when we should be looking forward to the Six Nations Championship. "I am very, very disappointed, more than you can imagine. Why do so many Scots have this knack of turning on each other when the going gets tough?"
llama3.2:1b: Calder fears Scottish rugby's professional football league could be damaged by a civil war over leadership and management issues, particularly with four members of the executive board resigning after disputes with the general committee.
Calder believes the decision will hurt Scotland's RBS Six Nations campaign and has expressed disappointment at the ongoing conflict.
llama3.2:3b: Finlay Calder fears civil war in Scottish rugby over boardroom resignations amid power struggle between executive and general committee, potentially impacting Six Nations campaign and national team's performance.
gemma2:2b: Calder is worried about civil war within the Scottish Rugby Union (SRU) which could hinder Scotland's RBS Six Nations campaign.
Four board members resigned due to a power struggle, with the chairman being ousted, and Calder believes this will impact professional rugby management negatively.
The situation could disrupt coaching efforts and signal instability in the SRU's financial position.

He believes Mackay, who controls the SRU's executive board, should have been promoted to head the club by David Mackay, the chairman.
However, Mackay resigned amid a simmering row over his role.
This highlights the power struggles within Scotland’s professional rugby scene and the potential for civil conflict that could undermine Scotland’s rugby ambitions.

Calder believes professional rugby should have been managed by professionals since professionalism arrived 10 years ago but thinks the decision will likely be reviewed by banks as well as potentially changing the work of Scotland's coaches.

Former Scotland international Finlay Calder criticizes David Mackay, SRU chairman who resigned along with four others in a power struggle with the general committee containing club-elected members.
Calder believes this decision will make it harder for coaches to address national side’s decline and questions why the issue of professionalism still persists 10 years after its introduction.
He expects banks, pulling the strings, might review their position and warns that ongoing arguments could hinder Scotland's preparations for upcoming Six Nations Championship.

Key players, including David Mackay, have resigned from the executive board.
Calder believes David, a successful businessman, is on the brink of change but others are upset about the power struggle.

tinyllama:1.1b: Scottish rugby is facing an uncertain future after four members of the executive board resigned following a simmering dispute with the Scottish Rugby Union's (SRU) general committee.

Despite Calder's statement, the SRU's chairman David Mackay has been driven out by an increasingly powerful group of professional players and administrators who are unhappy with the financial struggles and perceived lack of success on the field.
The power struggle between the executive board and the general committee could further damage Scotland's reputation as a nation that can manage its own rugby affairs.
Calder also expressed concerns about the impact of this issue on the wider picture, suggesting it would make the job of coaches and administrators even more difficult.
Despite the negative outcomes for Scottish rugby, Calder remained optimistic about the prospects of the Six Nations Championship, stating that he was disappointed but not surprised.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Former Scotland international Finlay Calder has expressed his dissatisfaction with the Scottish Rugby Union (SRU) executive board and board chairman, David Mackay, for allowing a power struggle among members.
According to Calder, he believes that this internal turmoil could significantly impact the upcoming Six Nations Championship campaign for Scotland's national rugby team.

He further states that, despite the negative atmosphere created by the power struggle within the executive board and board chairman, he hopes that David Mackay can transform the situation and restore professionalism to Scottish rugby.

Calder predicts further arguments and acrimony, which he believes will distract from preparations for the Six Nations Championship.
